header.title: Belief in, and Alleged Experience of, the Paranormal in Ostensible UFO Abductees

central_thesis: UFO abductees self-report significantly greater belief in, and alleged experience of, various paranormal phenomena (ESP, psychokinesis, and life after death) compared to a control group of students, thus confirming anecdotal reports. However, further research is needed before concluding that abductees are necessarily more 'psychic'; it is possible that alien abductions happen to people already prone to psychic encounters.

structure_content.summary: This section summarizes the study, stating that anecdotal reports link UFO phenomena to the paranormal. It details the administration of the 18-item Australian Sheep-Goat Scale to 21 self-selected UFO abductees and 301 student controls, finding significantly greater self-reported paranormal belief and experience among abductees, which confirmed the anecdotal reports. It cautions against concluding abductees are 'more psychic' without further research.

This section reviews existing literature and anecdotal observations that connect UFO encounters, particularly 'close encounters' and abduction experiences, with reports of paranormal events and abilities. It highlights the lack of prior statistical study on this correlation and sets the objective of the research: to statistically compare self-reported paranormal experiences in abductees versus a non-abductee control group.

This section explores various historical definitions of 'UFO abduction' from the literature, noting the evolution of the concept from the 1980s. It culminates in the specific, multi-criteria definition adopted for this study, adapted from the J. Allen Hynek Center for UFO Studies, which requires involuntary removal by non-human beings to a non-terrestrial enclosed space, subject to examination or communication, and remembered consciously or through focused concentration.

This section outlines the research methodology. Potential abductees were first screened using the adopted definition of abduction. Those who affirmed all criteria then completed the 18-item forced-choice Australian Sheep-Goat Scale, which assesses belief in and alleged experience of ESP, psychokinesis, and life after death, plus one item on post-abduction psychic changes. Packets were distributed across Australia, yielding 21 abductee participants. The control group consisted of 301 undergraduate psychology students.

This section presents the quantitative findings. Abductees scored significantly higher on the Australian Sheep-Goat Scale (mean 29.52) compared to the control group (mean 15.21), indicating greater belief in and experience of the paranormal. Detailed tables illustrate the frequency of 'true', 'uncertain', and 'false' responses for each of the 19 scale items, showing consistent patterns where abductees reported paranormal beliefs and experiences at significantly higher rates across all categories (ESP, precognition, telepathy, psychokinesis, and belief in life after death).

This section interprets the robust findings, emphasizing the extraordinarily high self-reported paranormal belief and experience among the surveyed abductees. It acknowledges potential self-selection bias but argues it was equally present in both groups. The discussion explores two primary explanations: that the results reflect real phenomena in abductees' lives, or that abductees are simply prone to alleging psychic events. The paper leans towards the latter, suggesting that alien abductions may not be 'psi-conducive' but rather occur to individuals already predisposed to psychic encounters.

key_concepts.definition: For the purpose of this study, an individual who has been taken against their will from normal, terrestrial surroundings by non-human beings, to another enclosed space (assumed to be a spacecraft) where they were subjected to examinations or communication, with these experiences remembered consciously or through focused concentration (e.g., hypnosis).
Encompasses phenomena such as Extrasensory Perception (ESP), Psychokinesis (PK), and belief in life after death, as measured by the Australian Sheep-Goat Scale.

An 18-item forced-choice questionnaire used to measure an individual's self-reported belief in and alleged experience of various paranormal phenomena (ESP, PK, life after death), with responses scored 'true' (2 points), 'uncertain' (1 point), or 'false' (0 points).

A general term for paranormal abilities including belief in its existence and having personal experiences of it, distinct from precognition or telepathy which are specified separately within the scale.
The ability to gain information about the future before it happens, in ways that do not depend on rational prediction or normal sensory channels, including having hunches or dreams that come true.

The direct influence of mind on a physical system without the mediation of any known physical energy, encompassing beliefs in its existence, personal exertion of PK, marked PK ability, and experiences of non-recurrent or persistent inexplicable physical disturbances (e.g., poltergeist activity).

The ability to gain information about another person's thoughts, feelings, or circumstances (receptive telepathy) or to send a 'mental message' or influence them at a distance (active telepathy) by non-normal sensory channels, including having personal experiences of it.

practical_system.description: This text does not describe a practical magical system. Instead, it details a research methodology designed to measure self-reported beliefs in and alleged experiences of paranormal phenomena among a specific population (UFO abductees) using a standardized psychometric instrument. The 'system' described is one of data collection and statistical comparison, not a set of operative magical techniques.

relevant_quotes.text: abductees reported significantly greater belief in, and alleged experience of, the paranormal (ESP, PK and life after death). The anecdotal reports were thus confirmed.
However, it should not be concluded until more research is carried out that the abductees are necessarily more psychic.
"You have been taken against your will from normal, terrestrial surroundings by non-human beings."
Perhaps, despite the anecdotal evidence, alien abductions are by and large not "psi-conducive", but happen to people who are highly prone to psychic encounters anyway.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is a quantitative psychological study investigating a correlation between self-reported anomalous experiences (UFO abductions) and self-reported paranormal beliefs/experiences. Its direct relevance to Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic is limited as it does not present a magical system or philosophy. Indirectly, it contributes to the empirical study of phenomena (like ESP and PK) that are often considered aspects of occult belief systems or indicators of latent magical ability, by examining their prevalence within a specific population claiming unusual experiences. It provides data on the 'experient' aspect often discussed in occult circles, albeit from a parapsychological viewpoint.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this paper includes researchers and academics in parapsychology, ufology, psychology, and anomalous experience studies. It is also relevant to individuals interested in the intersection of UFO phenomena and psychic abilities from an empirical perspective. It is not intended for practitioners of magic seeking instruction or theory within established occult traditions.
